messageBody:
blah Smiths solution sounds a little off base, i am assuming that
expects in JMock would work, but from the test i think he wants to do
a state test, so i think you should assert check if file was written
or not ? ...

Regards
Vyas, Anirudh



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Nat Pryce" <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>
> Logging is usually not a dependency. It's not *required* for the
object's
> functionality. It's merely a *notification* about what the object
is doing.
>
> --Nat
>
> On 07/11/2007, Stephen Smith <steve@...> wrote:
> >
> > Use the Dependency Injection pattern to inject your Logger into
your
> > class, and then use JMock or a similar mocking API
> > to assert that the logger is called with your expected parameters.
> >
> > ---
> > Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> > http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
> >
> > Nat Pryce wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > > I prefer to separate the notification of significant events
from the
> > logging
> > > (or other handling) of those events. It's easy to test the
notification
> > > with mock objects and then wire the notifications into a
logging system
> > in
> > > the production system.
> > >
> > > More info about doing this (in C#) at
> > > http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000488.html.
> > > <http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000488.html.>
> > > And an easy way to implement notifications in Java at
> > > http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000710.html.
> > > <http://nat.truemesh.com/archives/000710.html.>
> > >
> > > --Nat
> > >
